page.title: 15Farming changes near Alford
page.content: The area is not affected by industry but has been changed by modern technology. Ditches are polluted by surplus nitrogen run-off and the growth of blanketweed abounds. Sparrow hawks were almost exterminated in the 1960's by DDT but now, because the use of DDT and its group has been limited, the species has fortunately revived. Forestry, horticulture and agriculture have changed in response to economic and government pressure. Drainage and extensive fertiliser use are common. There are fewer meadows and pastures and more cultivated land. Woodland is becoming more coniferous and less deciduous with a resulting effect on the wildlife that relies on the broadleaf trees. One of the casualties of extensive drainage is the snipe, its traditional haunts shrinking fast.
